Generally, we are doing $A = P \Lambda P^-1$
Columns of $P$ are eigenvectors, $\Lambda$ contains eigenvalues

Means $A$ is diagonlizable

$A$ is a hard transformation to examine; $\Lambda$ just scales elements.
So we're scaling ${[x]}_\mathscr{P}$ and then mapping back into $x$

If we have distinct eigenvalues (and their corresponding eigenvectors) then they are linearly independent, and they span $\mathbb{R}^n$, so they form a basis for it.
This also means we can diagonalize $A$

Construct $A$: $A = P \Lambda P^{-1}$
We can make any $\Lambda$ we want, and take $P = LU$ such that $P^{-1} = U^{-1}L^{-1}$

We take $L,U$ as lower and upper unit triangular
